book_summary.overall_summary:
Venture Deals is a practical, inside‑out guide to how venture capital financings actually work, aimed at entrepreneurs, their lawyers, and new entrants to the startup finance ecosystem. The book opens by mapping the players — founders, angels, VCs, syndicates, lawyers and mentors — and explains their differing motivations and incentives. Using the historical AR&D/DEC example and decades of deal experience, the authors show how simple investment letters evolved into today’s multi‑page term sheets and argue that every negotiation reduces to two core levers: economics (who gets what) and control (who makes or blocks decisions).

From that framing the text walks readers through the anatomy of term sheets: valuation and price mechanics, liquidation preferences and participation, option pool sizing, vesting, dilution protections (antidilution), board composition and protective provisions. Interleaved throughout are entrepreneur‑focused sidebars and tactical advice: when to insist on written employment terms, how to handle no‑shop clauses, the practical meaning of information and registration rights, and sensible approaches to co‑sale and ROFR provisions. The authors emphasize that a signed term sheet starts the binding negotiation path rather than completes it and caution founders to watch for provisions that are accidentally made binding.

The book also covers the tools founders most need: how to build and validate a capitalization table, how convertible debt (notes and SAFEs) works and where it can create pitfalls, and the essential legal hygiene every founder must understand (employment arrangements, 83(b) elections, corporate form selection, indemnification and D&O insurance). Practical numeric examples and cap‑table algebra demystify dilution math and show how post‑money option pools dilute founders, not incoming investors.

Finally, Venture Deals steps back to place startups in context with a short manifesto on ecosystem building (the Boulder Thesis): entrepreneurship clusters because of real, local advantages and succeed best when entrepreneur‑led, long‑term, inclusive, and activity‑driven. Overall, the book combines deal mechanics, negotiation strategy, legal reminders and community wisdom into a single handbook that helps readers negotiate smarter, avoid common traps, and align incentives for long‑term company building.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 1, "The Players," maps the ecosystem of people and institutions that populate the venture-capital process and explains their motivations and roles. It profiles the entrepreneur (product and company builder whose goals are growth and control), the venture capitalist (focused on portfolio returns, staged investing, and governance), angels (early, often founder-friendly capital providers), syndicates (groups of investors that share risk and carry influence), lawyers (who translate business deals into binding documents), and mentors (who provide advisory and network value). The chapter also clarifies financing-round nomenclature (seed, Series A/B/C, growth rounds) and the different types of VC firms (seed/early-stage, later-stage, corporate, micro-VC), giving entrepreneurs a practical vocabulary for understanding who they will be dealing with and why each player behaves the way they do.

Building on the Introduction's framing of the "art of the term sheet," this chapter shows that term-sheet outcomes are the product of personalities, incentives, and market roles as much as they are of technical legal clauses. It emphasizes how the choice of investor—lead versus syndicate member, angel versus institutional VC—affects negotiation leverage, governance expectations, due-diligence intensity, and the kinds of protective/control provisions investors will demand. By mapping who participates in a financing and how they interact, the chapter sets the stage for the later, more detailed discussions of economic and control terms in Chapters 3–6 and the practical fundraising steps in Chapter 2.

Foreword

remember the first week of my career as a VC. I was 25 years
old, it was 1986, and I had just landed a summer job in a venture
capital firm. I was working for three experienced venture capitalists
in a small firm called Euclid Partners, where I ended up spending
the first 10 years of my VC career. One of those three partners,
Bliss McCrum, peeked his head into my office (I had an office in
Rockefeller Center at age 25) and said to me, "Can you model out
a financing for XYZ Company at a $9 million pre-money, raising
$3 million, with an unissued option pool of 10%?" and then went
back to the big office in the rear he shared with the other founding
partner, Milton Pappas.

I sat at my desk and started thinking about the request. I
understood the "raising $3 million" bit. I thought I could figure
out the "unissued option pool of 10%" bit. But what the hell was
"pre-money"? I had never heard that term. This was almost a decade
before Netscape and Internet search so searching online for it wasn't
an option. After spending ten minutes getting up the courage, I
walked back to that big office, peeked my head in, and said to Bliss,
"Can you explain pre-money to me?"

Thus began my 31-year education in venture capital that is still
going on as I write this.

The venture capital business was a cottage industry back in 1985,
with club deals and a language all of its own. A cynic would say it was
designed this way to be opaque to everyone other than the VCs so that
they would have all the leverage in negotiations with entrepreneurs.
I don't entirely buy that narrative. I think the VC business grew up in
a few small offices in Boston, New York, and San Francisco, and the
dozens-maybe as many as a hundred-of main participants, along

<!-- PageBreak -->

with their lawyers, came up with structures that made sense to them.
They then developed a shorthand so that they could communicate
among themselves.

But whatever the origin story was, the language of venture deals
is foreign to many and remains opaque and confusing to this day.
This works to the advantage of industry insiders and to the disadvan-
tage of those who are new to startups and venture capital.

In the early 2000s, after I wound down my first venture capital
firm, Flatiron Partners, and before we started USV, I started blogging.
One of my goals with my AVC blog (at www.avc.com) was to bring
transparency to this opaque world that I had been inhabiting for
almost 20 years. I was joined in this blogging thing by Brad Feld, a
friend and frequent coinvestor. Club investing has not gone away
and that's a good thing. By reading AVC and Feld Thoughts regu-
larly, an entrepreneur could get up to speed on startups and venture
capital. Brad and I received a tremendous amount of positive feed-
back on our efforts to bring transparency to the venture capital busi-
ness so we kept doing it, and now if you search for something like
"participating preferred" you will find posts written by both me and
Brad on that first search results page.

Brad and his partner Jason Mendelson (a recovering startup law-
yer turned VC) took things a step further and wrote a book called
Venture Deals back in 2011. It has turned into a classic and is now on
its Third Edition. If Venture Deals had been around in 1985, I would
not have had to admit to Bliss that I had no idea what pre-money
meant.

If there is a guidebook to navigating the mysterious and confusing
language of venture capital and venture capital financing structures,
it is Venture Deals. Anyone interested in startups, entrepreneurship,
and angel and venture capital financings should do themselves a
favor and read it.

Fred Wilson
USV Partner
July 2016

Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet

0
ne of the first famous venture capital investments was Digital
Equipment Corporation (DEC). In 1957, American Research and
Development Corporation (AR&D), one of the first venture capital
firms, invested $70,000 in DEC. When DEC went public in 1968, this
investment was worth over $355 million, or a return of over 5,000
times the invested capital. AR&D's investment in DEC was one of the
original venture capital home runs.

In 1957, the venture capital industry was just being created. At the
time, the investor community in the United States was uninterested
in investing in computer companies, as the last wave of computer-
related startups had performed poorly and even large companies
were having difficulty making money in the computer business. We
can envision the frustration of DEC's cofounders, Ken Olson and
Harlan Anderson, as the investors they talked to rejected them
and their fledgling idea for a business. We can also imagine their
joy when Georges Doriot, the founder of American Research and
Development Corporation, offered to fund them. After a number
of conversations and meetings, Doriot sent Olson and Anderson a
letter expressing his interest in investing, along with his proposed
terms. Today, this document is called the term sheet.

Now, imagine what that term sheet looked like. There are three
different possibilities. The first is that it was a typed one-page let-
ter that said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your company
and buy 78 percent of it." The next is that it was two pages of legal
terms that basically said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your
company and buy 78 percent of it." Or it could have been an eight-
page typed document that had all kinds of protective provisions, vesting

<!-- PageNumber="1" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="2" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals" -->

arrangements, drag-along rights, and Securities and Exchange Com-
mission (SEC) registration rights.

Our guess is that it was not the third option. Over the past 50
years, the art of the term sheet has evolved and expanded, reaching
its current eight (or so) page literary masterpiece. These eight pages
contain a lot more than "We'd like to invest $X in your company
and get Y% of it," but, as you'll learn, there really are only two key
things that matter in the actual term sheet negotiation-economics
and control.

In DEC's case, by owning 78% of the company, AR&D effec-
tively had control of the company. And the price was clearly
defined-$70,000 bought 78% of the company, resulting in a $90,000
post-money valuation.

Today's venture capital investments have many more nuances.
Individual venture capitalists (VCs) usually end up owning less than
50 percent of the company, so they don't have effective voting con-
trol but often negotiate provisions that give them control over major
decisions by the company. Many companies end up with multiple
venture capitalists who invest in the company at different points in
time, resulting in different ownership percentages, varying rights,
and diverging motivations. Founders don't always stay with the com-
pany through the exit and, in some cases, they end up leaving rela-
tively early in the life of a company for a variety of reasons. Compa-
nies fail, so venture capitalists have gotten much more focused on
protecting themselves for the downside as well as participating in the
upside. Governance issues are always complex, especially when you
have a lot of people sitting around the negotiating table.

While it would be desirable to do venture capital deals with a
simple agreement on price, a handshake, and a short legal agree-
ment, this rarely happens. And while there have been plenty of
attempts to standardize the term sheet over the years, the prolifera-
tion of lawyers, venture capitalists, and entrepreneurs, along with a
steadily increasing number of investments, has prevented this from
happening. Ironically, the actual definitive documents have become
more standard over time. Whether it is the Internet age that has
spread information across the ecosystem or clients growing tired of
paying legal bills, there are more similarities in the documents today
than ever before. As a result, we can lend you our experience in how
venture financings are usually done. The good news is once you've

<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="3" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet" -->

negotiated the term sheet, you are done with the hard part. As a
result, that's where we are going to focus our energy in this book.

Throughout this book we will cover not only the what and the
how, but also the why things work as they do. Let's begin our explora-
tion of venture capital financings by discussing the various players
involved.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Overview of the Term Sheet

A
t the end of 2005, during the dark ages when venture capital was
very much out of favor, we participated in a financing that was much
more difficult than it needed to be. All of the participants were to
blame, and ignorance of what really mattered in the negotiation
kept things going much longer than was necessary. We talked about
what to do and, at the risk of giving away super-top-secret venture
capital magic tricks, decided to write a blog series on Brad's blog
(Feld Thoughts-www.feld.com) that deconstructed a venture capital
term sheet and explained each section.

That blog series was the inspiration for this book. The next few
chapters cover the most frequently discussed terms in a venture capi-
tal term sheet. Many venture capitalists (VCs) love to negotiate hard
on every term as though the health of their children depended on
them getting the terms just right. Sometimes this is inexperience on
the part of the VC; often, it's just a negotiating tactic.

The specific language that we refer to is from actual term sheets.
In addition to describing and explaining the specific terms, we give
you examples of what to focus on and implications from the perspec-
tives of the company, VCs, and entrepreneurs.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 5 builds directly on the book’s mission (introduced in the Foreword and Preface) to demystify term‑sheet language by laying out the two meta‑principles that govern virtually every VC negotiation: economics and control. It reviews the economic levers—price/valuation, liquidation preference, option pool sizing, warrants and bridge financing, pay‑to‑play, vesting and exercise periods, dividends, redemption rights, and antidilution mechanics (full ratchet vs. weighted average and broad vs. narrow bases)—and explains how each affects investor returns and founder dilution. The chapter also covers control levers: board composition, protective provisions, conversion and automatic conversion thresholds, class voting dynamics, and the practical risks of poorly drafted consent/trigger terms. Practical entrepreneur‑side guidance runs through the chapter (e.g., prepare an option budget, avoid unnecessary warrants, prefer balanced vesting and double‑trigger acceleration, equalize automatic conversion thresholds across series, and resist vague adverse‑change redemption clauses). 

This chapter sharpens the themes introduced in the Introduction (Chapter 4) about how term sheets evolved from simple offers into dense, lawyerly documents by showing which clauses materially matter and which are often negotiation theater. It emphasizes how many term‑sheet disputes reduce to fights over economics or control, and it gives entrepreneurs concrete negotiating strategies and cautionary examples (antidilution math, board seat balance, investor voting mechanics, and conditions precedent that mask deal escape hatches). The chapter closes by reminding readers that term sheets are usually nonbinding and that entrepreneurs should watch for clauses investors make binding (no‑shop, legal fees, governing law) while reserving the right to confirm understandings in definitive agreements.

chapter_summaries.summary:
This chapter gives the entrepreneur’s point of view on the practical realities of negotiating and signing a term sheet. Building on the book’s earlier discussion of why term sheets exist (Chapter 4) and the two meta‑principles of every negotiation—economics and control (Chapter 5)—the authors focus on the timing and specificity of key deal terms. The single most important tactical takeaway is: if the term sheet contains a no‑shop clause that restricts you from soliciting other investors, insist that any material employment and management terms (CEO role, compensation, equity vesting, change‑in‑control protections, board seats, etc.) be spelled out before you sign. A VC’s refusal to commit to these basics early is a clear red flag because a signed no‑shop gives them leverage while you remain exposed.

The chapter also warns that many idiosyncratic and punitive provisions have been used in the past—if you can dream it, someone has probably tried it—so read the contract carefully. It underscores an important process point emphasized earlier: a signed term sheet is not the same as a closed deal. Boilerplate paragraphs and odd conditions can impose obligations or contingencies that change the economics or control consequences you thought were agreed. Entrepreneurs should therefore use counsel, push for clarity on critical items up front, and treat the term sheet as the beginning of a binding negotiation path rather than the finish line.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 7 shifts the lens to the entrepreneur’s practical stance on one of the most common provisions in term sheets: information rights. Building on the book’s earlier explanations of why term sheets exist (Chapter 4) and the two meta‑principles—economics and control (Chapter 5)—the chapter argues that entrepreneurs should default to transparency. It explains that routine delivery of budgets, financial statements, and periodic reporting is both a reasonable expectation from investors and a useful discipline for the company. The authors warn that if a founder cannot commit to these basic reporting obligations, they should not take outside capital, because information rights are a fundamental part of how investors exercise control and monitor their economics.

The chapter is also pragmatic about tradeoffs. It counsels entrepreneurs to keep reporting obligations sensible and operationally feasible so that compliance does not become a crippling burden on a small team. At the same time, it recommends protecting sensitive details with a confidentiality clause if the founder is concerned about competitive exposure. In short, the entrepreneur’s perspective presented here treats information rights as a low‑cost, high‑value governance tool: easy to grant, important to investors, useful to founders, and negotiable in scope and frequency to preserve founder bandwidth and company confidentiality.

The Capitalization Table N. ow that we've worked through all of the specific clauses in the term sheet, let's go through how a typical capitalization table (cap table) works. A term sheet will almost always contain a summary cap table, which we describe in this chapter. You, your prospective investors, or occasionally your lawyers will generate a more detailed cap table. The cap table summarizes who owns what part of the company before and after the financing. This is one area that some founders, especially those who have not been exposed in the past to cap table math, are often uncomfortable with. It's extremely important for founders to understand exactly who owns what part of a company and what the implications are in a potential funding round. Normally when you initially set up the company, 100% will be allocated to the founders and employees, with a specific number of shares allocated to each individual. The question "What will I own if a venture capitalist invests X in my company at a Y valuation?" is rarely simple. To answer it, you need to be able to generate a cap table to truly analyze the deal presented by a particular term sheet. Following is a model to work from with a typical example. Let's assume the following: 2 million shares held by founders before the VC invests $10 million pre-money valuation $5 million investment by the VC In this example, the post-money valuation is $15 million ($10 mil- lion pre-money + $5 million investment). Consequently, the VCs own 33.33% of the company after the financing ($5 million invest- ment/$15 million post-money valuation). This should be pretty straightforward so far. Now, assume the term sheet includes a new employee option pool of 20% on a post-money basis. Remember that this means that after the financing, there will be an unallocated option pool equal to 20% of the company. Although the post-money valuation remains the same ($15 mil- lion), the requirement for a 20% option pool will have a significant impact on the ownership of the founders. Per the cap table, you can see how we calculate the percentage ownership for each class of owner, along with the price per share of the preferred stock. To start, we've filled in the known numbers and now have to solve for the unknowns (A, B, C, D, and E). First, let's solve for A, the founders' ownership percentage: A = 100% minus the VC percentage minus the employee pool percent- age, or 100% - 33.33% - 20% = 46.67%. Given that we know that the 2 million founders' shares represent 46.67% of the company, we can determine that the total shares outstanding (E = 2 million/ 0.4667) are 4,285,408. Now, if there are 4,285,408 shares outstanding, deter- mining the number of shares in the employee pool becomes B = E *0.20 or 857,081. The same math applies for C, the number of shares of preferred stock the VCs have. C = E * 0.3333 or 1,428,326. Since $5 million bought 1,428,326 shares of preferred stock, then the price per share of preferred stock (D = $5 million/1,428,326) is $3.50 per share. Finally, always check your calculation. Since we know we have a $10 million pre-money valuation, then the shares prior to the financ- ing (2 million founders' shares plus the 20% option pool) times the price per share should equal $10 million. Convertible Debt

I,
n the past few chapters we've gone through, in detail, the terms
in a typical venture capital equity financing. However, there is one
other type of financing, often used at the seed stage, called a con-
vertible debt financing. In fact, many angel investors will invest only
with this structure.

Convertible debt is just that: debt. It's a loan. The loan will con-
vert to equity (preferred stock, usually) at such time as another
round is raised. The conversion usually includes some sort of dis-
count on the price to the future round.

For example, assume you raise $500,000 in convertible debt
from angels with a 20% discount to the next round, and six months
later a venture capitalist (VC) offers to lead a Series A round of a
$1 million investment at $1 a share. Your financing will actually be
for $1.5 million total, although the VCs will get 1 million Series A
shares ($1 million at $1 per share) and the angels will get 625,000
Series A shares ($500,000 at $0.80 per share). The discount is appro-
priate, as your early investors want some reward for investing before
the full Series A financing round comes together.

In this chapter, we cover the arguments for and against using
convertible debt. We then go through the terms in a convertible
debt deal, including the discount, valuation caps, interest rate, con-
version mechanics, conversion in a sale of the company, warrants,
and other terms. We briefly cover the differences between early-stage
and late-stage dynamics and finish up with an example of when con-
vertible debt could be dangerous to use.

Venture Deals is a practical, inside‑out guide to how venture capital financings actually work, aimed at entrepreneurs, their lawyers, and new entrants to the startup finance ecosystem. Using the historical AR&D/DEC example and decades of deal experience, the authors show how simple investment letters evolved into today’s multi‑page term sheets and argue that every negotiation reduces to two core levers: economics (who gets what) and control (who makes or blocks decisions).

Interleaved throughout are entrepreneur‑focused sidebars and tactical advice: when to insist on written employment terms, how to handle no‑shop clauses, the practical meaning of information and registration rights, and sensible approaches to co‑sale and ROFR provisions. The book also covers the tools founders most need: how to build and validate a capitalization table, how convertible debt (notes and SAFEs) works and where it can create pitfalls, and the essential legal hygiene every founder must understand (employment arrangements, 83(b) elections, corporate form selection, indemnification and D&O insurance). Practical numeric examples and cap‑table algebra demystify dilution math and show how post‑money option pools dilute founders, not incoming investors.

Finally, Venture Deals steps back to place startups in context with a short manifesto on ecosystem building (the Boulder Thesis): entrepreneurship clusters because of real, local advantages and succeed best when entrepreneur‑led, long‑term, inclusive, and activity‑driven. remember the first week of my career as a VC. I was 25 years
old, it was 1986, and I had just landed a summer job in a venture
capital firm. I was working for three experienced venture capitalists
in a small firm called Euclid Partners, where I ended up spending
the first 10 years of my VC career. One of those three partners,
Bliss McCrum, peeked his head into my office (I had an office in
Rockefeller Center at age 25) and said to me, "Can you model out
a financing for XYZ Company at a $9 million pre-money, raising
$3 million, with an unissued option pool of 10%?" and then went
back to the big office in the rear he shared with the other founding
partner, Milton Pappas.

I sat at my desk and started thinking about the request. I
understood the "raising $3 million" bit. I thought I could figure
out the "unissued option pool of 10%" bit. But what the hell was
"pre-money"? I had never heard that term. This was almost a decade
before Netscape and Internet search so searching online for it wasn't
an option. After spending ten minutes getting up the courage, I
walked back to that big office, peeked my head in, and said to Bliss,
"Can you explain pre-money to me?"

Thus began my 31-year education in venture capital that is still
going on as I write this.

The venture capital business was a cottage industry back in 1985,
with club deals and a language all of its own. A cynic would say it was
designed this way to be opaque to everyone other than the VCs so that
they would have all the leverage in negotiations with entrepreneurs.
I don't entirely buy that narrative. I think the VC business grew up in
a few small offices in Boston, New York, and San Francisco, and the
dozens-maybe as many as a hundred-of main participants, along

In the early 2000s, after I wound down my first venture capital

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet

0
ne of the first famous venture capital investments was Digital
Equipment Corporation (DEC). In 1957, American Research and
Development Corporation (AR&D), one of the first venture capital
firms, invested $70,000 in DEC. When DEC went public in 1968, this
investment was worth over $355 million, or a return of over 5,000
times the invested capital. AR&D's investment in DEC was one of the
original venture capital home runs.

In 1957, the venture capital industry was just being created. At the
time, the investor community in the United States was uninterested
in investing in computer companies, as the last wave of computer-
related startups had performed poorly and even large companies
were having difficulty making money in the computer business. We
can envision the frustration of DEC's cofounders, Ken Olson and
Harlan Anderson, as the investors they talked to rejected them
and their fledgling idea for a business. We can also imagine their
joy when Georges Doriot, the founder of American Research and
Development Corporation, offered to fund them. After a number
of conversations and meetings, Doriot sent Olson and Anderson a
letter expressing his interest in investing, along with his proposed
terms. Today, this document is called the term sheet.

Now, imagine what that term sheet looked like. There are three
different possibilities. The first is that it was a typed one-page let-
ter that said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your company
and buy 78 percent of it." The next is that it was two pages of legal
terms that basically said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your
company and buy 78 percent of it." Or it could have been an eight-
page typed document that had all kinds of protective provisions, vesting

<!-- PageNumber="1" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="2" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals" -->

arrangements, drag-along rights, and Securities and Exchange Com-
mission (SEC) registration rights.

Our guess is that it was not the third option. Over the past 50
years, the art of the term sheet has evolved and expanded, reaching
its current eight (or so) page literary masterpiece. These eight pages
contain a lot more than "We'd like to invest $X in your company
and get Y% of it," but, as you'll learn, there really are only two key
things that matter in the actual term sheet negotiation-economics
and control.

In DEC's case, by owning 78% of the company, AR&D effec-
tively had control of the company. And the price was clearly
defined-$70,000 bought 78% of the company, resulting in a $90,000
post-money valuation.

Today's venture capital investments have many more nuances.
Individual venture capitalists (VCs) usually end up owning less than
50 percent of the company, so they don't have effective voting con-
trol but often negotiate provisions that give them control over major
decisions by the company. Many companies end up with multiple
venture capitalists who invest in the company at different points in
time, resulting in different ownership percentages, varying rights,
and diverging motivations. Founders don't always stay with the com-
pany through the exit and, in some cases, they end up leaving rela-
tively early in the life of a company for a variety of reasons. Compa-
nies fail, so venture capitalists have gotten much more focused on
protecting themselves for the downside as well as participating in the
upside. Governance issues are always complex, especially when you
have a lot of people sitting around the negotiating table.

While it would be desirable to do venture capital deals with a
simple agreement on price, a handshake, and a short legal agree-
ment, this rarely happens. And while there have been plenty of
attempts to standardize the term sheet over the years, the prolifera-
tion of lawyers, venture capitalists, and entrepreneurs, along with a
steadily increasing number of investments, has prevented this from
happening. Ironically, the actual definitive documents have become
more standard over time. Whether it is the Internet age that has
spread information across the ecosystem or clients growing tired of
paying legal bills, there are more similarities in the documents today
than ever before. As a result, we can lend you our experience in how
venture financings are usually done. The good news is once you've

<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="3" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet" -->

negotiated the term sheet, you are done with the hard part. As a
result, that's where we are going to focus our energy in this book.

Throughout this book we will cover not only the what and the
how, but also the why things work as they do. Let's begin our explora-
tion of venture capital financings by discussing the various players
involved.

very much out of favor, we participated in a financing that was much

This chapter sharpens the themes introduced in the Introduction (Chapter 4) about how term sheets evolved from simple offers into dense, lawyerly documents by showing which clauses materially matter and which are often negotiation theater. It emphasizes how many term‑sheet disputes reduce to fights over economics or control, and it gives entrepreneurs concrete negotiating strategies and cautionary examples (antidilution math, board seat balance, investor voting mechanics, and conditions precedent that mask deal escape hatches). The chapter closes by reminding readers that term sheets are usually nonbinding and that entrepreneurs should watch for clauses investors make binding (no‑shop, legal fees, governing law) while reserving the right to confirm understandings in definitive agreements.

Boilerplate paragraphs and odd conditions can impose obligations or contingencies that change the economics or control consequences you thought were agreed. The authors situate the ROFR in the context of changing market realities: historically founders were tightly restricted from selling until investors could exit, but the growth of secondary markets and longer private company life cycles have shifted practices and made selective, controlled secondary sales more common.

The entrepreneurial recommendation is pragmatic: entrepreneurs generally shouldn't fight ROFRs because they help preserve a controlled shareholder base, which benefits the company and most shareholders, and the clause gives management visibility and decision authority over private transfers (important amid greater SEC scrutiny of private ownership rules). That said, entrepreneurs should negotiate definitions and scope—limit transfer rights to "major investors" (and define that term) or condition rights on participation in subsequent rounds—so that ROFRs protect the company without granting blanket veto power to minor shareholders.

The Capitalization Table N. ow that we've worked through all of the specific clauses in the term sheet, let's go through how a typical capitalization table (cap table) works. A term sheet will almost always contain a summary cap table, which we describe in this chapter. You, your prospective investors, or occasionally your lawyers will generate a more detailed cap table. The cap table summarizes who owns what part of the company before and after the financing. This is one area that some founders, especially those who have not been exposed in the past to cap table math, are often uncomfortable with. It's extremely important for founders to understand exactly who owns what part of a company and what the implications are in a potential funding round. Normally when you initially set up the company, 100% will be allocated to the founders and employees, with a specific number of shares allocated to each individual. The question "What will I own if a venture capitalist invests X in my company at a Y valuation?" is rarely simple. To answer it, you need to be able to generate a cap table to truly analyze the deal presented by a particular term sheet. Following is a model to work from with a typical example. Let's assume the following: 2 million shares held by founders before the VC invests $10 million pre-money valuation $5 million investment by the VC In this example, the post-money valuation is $15 million ($10 mil- lion pre-money + $5 million investment). Consequently, the VCs own 33.33% of the company after the financing ($5 million invest- ment/$15 million post-money valuation). This should be pretty straightforward so far. Now, assume the term sheet includes a new employee option pool of 20% on a post-money basis. Remember that this means that after the financing, there will be an unallocated option pool equal to 20% of the company. Although the post-money valuation remains the same ($15 mil- lion), the requirement for a 20% option pool will have a significant impact on the ownership of the founders. Per the cap table, you can see how we calculate the percentage ownership for each class of owner, along with the price per share of the preferred stock. To start, we've filled in the known numbers and now have to solve for the unknowns (A, B, C, D, and E). First, let's solve for A, the founders' ownership percentage: A = 100% minus the VC percentage minus the employee pool percent- age, or 100% - 33.33% - 20% = 46.67%. Given that we know that the 2 million founders' shares represent 46.67% of the company, we can determine that the total shares outstanding (E = 2 million/ 0.4667) are 4,285,408. Now, if there are 4,285,408 shares outstanding, deter- mining the number of shares in the employee pool becomes B = E *0.20 or 857,081. The same math applies for C, the number of shares of preferred stock the VCs have. C = E * 0.3333 or 1,428,326. Since $5 million bought 1,428,326 shares of preferred stock, then the price per share of preferred stock (D = $5 million/1,428,326) is $3.50 per share. Finally, always check your calculation. Since we know we have a $10 million pre-money valuation, then the shares prior to the financ- ing (2 million founders' shares plus the 20% option pool) times the price per share should equal $10 million. While this is close enough for an example, it's not close enough for most VCs, or for most lawyers for that matter. And it shouldn't be close enough for you. There are a lot of good lawyers out there with poor math skills, and the cap table can get messed up when left in the hands of the lawyers. chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Convertible Debt

I,
n the past few chapters we've gone through, in detail, the terms
in a typical venture capital equity financing. However, there is one
other type of financing, often used at the seed stage, called a con-
vertible debt financing. In fact, many angel investors will invest only
with this structure.

Convertible debt is just that: debt. It's a loan. The loan will con-
vert to equity (preferred stock, usually) at such time as another
round is raised. The conversion usually includes some sort of dis-
count on the price to the future round.

For example, assume you raise $500,000 in convertible debt
from angels with a 20% discount to the next round, and six months
later a venture capitalist (VC) offers to lead a Series A round of a
$1 million investment at $1 a share. Your financing will actually be
for $1.5 million total, although the VCs will get 1 million Series A
shares ($1 million at $1 per share) and the angels will get 625,000
Series A shares ($500,000 at $0.80 per share). The discount is appro-
priate, as your early investors want some reward for investing before
the full Series A financing round comes together.

In this chapter, we cover the arguments for and against using
convertible debt. We then go through the terms in a convertible
debt deal, including the discount, valuation caps, interest rate, con-
version mechanics, conversion in a sale of the company, warrants,
and other terms. We briefly cover the differences between early-stage
and late-stage dynamics and finish up with an example of when con-
vertible debt could be dangerous to use.

chapter_summaries.summary: Chapter 13 introduces convertible debt (notes) as a common seed-stage financing alternative to a priced equity round, and explains both the economics and the legal mechanics founders must watch. It defines a convertible note as a loan that typically converts into preferred equity at the next qualifying financing, often at a discount to the new round price. The chapter walks through key commercial terms — discount, valuation cap, interest, maturity and automatic conversion triggers, qualified financing thresholds, amendment/consent mechanics, and the treatment of notes in an acquisition — and explains how each term affects dilution, timing, and control. It also covers less common add-ons such as warrants (including term length, merger treatment, and original issue discount accounting), and contrasts convertible notes with newer standardized instruments (SAFE, KISS), highlighting trade-offs (maturity and leverage, investor protections like pro rata, and simplicity). chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 15 shifts the focus from deal mechanics and legal hygiene to the macro question of why startups cluster and how communities that support entrepreneurship form and persist. After summarizing three classic explanations for geographic concentration—economics (external or agglomeration economies), sociology, and geography (the “spikiness” of creative activity)—the author proposes a practical, experience‑based alternative: the Boulder Thesis. The thesis prescribes four actionable pillars for building a vibrant startup ecosystem: entrepreneurs must lead it; leaders must commit for the long term (roughly a 20‑year horizon); the community must be inclusive; and it must sustain continual, hands‑on activities that engage the entire entrepreneurial stack.

The chapter stresses that place matters more than ever despite digital connectivity, because shared infrastructure, specialized services, talent pools, and dense networks lower transaction and coordination costs. It also emphasizes the need for sustained, iterative experimentation—hackathons, accelerators, meetups and similar activities—that actually engage founders, mentors, investors, employees and service providers rather than one‑off PR events. Finally, it argues that a genuine community is entrepreneur‑led and resilient through economic cycles, because building lasting companies and ecosystems takes far longer than short political or economic windows allow.
